 The implication of the universe being self existent denies the physical evidence (the big bang for instance). Also, that which is self existent must, logically be relational. Otherwise there is no "self" to be existent. Physical laws are not "defined" by man as you say but rather discovered. There is no Physicist on the planet that would state that he created gravity or entropy or conservation of energy etc. Some might claim discovery of such things. Never definition of such things.
 
 The act of defining is just that, it is an act. An action. 
 
 I think you should re-examine the physical laws and "origins of the universe" evidence. The current evidence points to variability in the speed of light, a universe without boundary, yet finite (or conversely an infinite universe with a boundary).
 
 What confounds me is that people actually think the universe always was. Especially given the evidence. The universe had a beginning and will end (entropy). The question I pose, is what is and will be or exists outside of time. That is a difficult one to stick into a verb tense (as tense implies time while outside of time implies.......well.......outside of time.

 Let's look at gravity. I completely disagree with your use of the term defined and how it is applied in this case.
 
 We didn't "discover" gravity, it's been all around us for as long as we've existed, whether we were conscious of it or not, we simply defined this phenomenon that we have observed. We (Newton gets the credit) define gravity as the force of attraction between two bodies that have mass. No one would say Newton discovered gravity, they would say that he defined gravity using specific observations, tests, and mathemathical proofs.
 
 I think I see your point in that man didn't create the universe or the laws it operates by, I agree with you. All we do is define those laws, or at least attempt to define them, according to the best of our current ability and understanding, in the terms and language that we have available to us.
 
 I'm lost as to "defining" being an act not an action, that makes no sense to me.
 
 It's been a while, but IIRC, the Big Bang relies on there being some infinitely dense particle that exploded to form the universe. Where did the particle come from? Is the particle truly separate from the current universe as we know it? Or is the current universe simply an extension of the particle that has always been?
 
 The rest of the "self existant" part of your post is quite honestly over my head, and beyond that which I care to discuss.
 
 I haven't seen any evidence to cause me to believe other than the universe simply "always was". Whether that be in the current form or not. I'm open to that evidence though.
 
 Why does anything have to exist outside of time? Why does there have to be something beyond our physical and spatial understanding of the universe? I don't get it. Why is that required in order for people to accept life and the universe?

 The book Flatland by Abbot provides an interesting look at this. You see, we are able to measure time, but not create, change or redirect it. Therefore one could consider that it is a dimension that we only move through. Much like the flat little square (two dimensional fictional being in the book) is moved through the dimension of "Up" by a sphere. He first experiences the sphere as a point and then ever increasing circles then ever decreasing circles and a point again and then the whole thing happens again in reverse as he is moved through "down". He has no control over it and yet it is there. We can accept time as a dimension that is beyond our ability to interact with other than measure.
 
 For something to be eternal "always was and will be" it must logically exist outside of time. Or "before" time if you will. The bible describes God in that way (the alpha and omega, the beginning and the end the "I am", was, is, and is to come).
 
 Infinitely dense particle is one in which it has no dimensions (remember density is measured by mass divided by volume. The only way it is infinite is if the volume is zero or the mass is infinite. We can and have measured (roughly) the mass of the universe using gravitational theory. It is far from infinite. The only other option then is that volume is zero. For this to be true, the mass must at one point have not existed.
 
 Thereby, something from nothing. The universe cannot simply have always been. For specific data, I would refer you to Stephen Hawking's brief history of time. He has many good equations and theories there. There are other astrophysical data availble with a simple internet search.

 I think we are not as far away in what we are saying. I say that to define something means to give authority to what something is. To define means to SET parameters as to the nature of something. Gravity was discovered. You are correct when you say it has been around for as long as we existed. We did not create it. One could say (linguistically speaking) that we gave definition to it, but we did not define what it would be. We described what it already was. That is the distinction I am trying to make.

 You lost me on why the universe must exist outside of time. I don't recall stating that, in fact, I would argue the opposite. 
 
 My simple explanation, based on the KISS theory, is that as far as our understanding and ability to measure time is concerned, severely limited as you've pointed out, the universe IS infinite, we can't determine when it started, we can't determine when it will end. We can guess, even make some educated guesses based on the available data, but we certainly can't be anywhere near certain of a beginning or an end.
 
 Why could time not have started the instant the universe started? Why did there have to be something before? Does time exist where there is nothing?
 
 Why can't time end when the universe ends? Just that simple, like turning off a switch. No time equals no universe, if nothing exists, how can it be related to time?
 
 I'm not going to pretend to be even in the same ballpark as Stephen Hawking, not even close, but IMHO, people make issues like this far more complex than they need be.

We can and have measured (roughly) the mass of the universe using gravitational theory. It is far from infinite. The only other option then is that volume is zero. For this to be true, the mass must at one point have not existed.
 
 Thereby, something from nothing. The universe cannot simply have always been. For specific data, I would refer you to Stephen Hawking's brief history of time. He has many good equations and theories there. There are other astrophysical data availble with a simple internet search.

 I'm not trying to get into an in depth mathematical approach to this, (obviously :) ) only what IMHO amounts to rather simple common sense when dealing with issues like this.

 I was working from your statement, which is correct, that the big bang assumes an infinitely dense particle. Look back at your posts. The data add up to infinite density.  Common sense is handy for living life in most cases. But the question here is one that is not that simple based on the available data. If it is so simple, why then are the most brilliant minds on the planet at odds about it?
 
 The truth is, it is not a simple question. It is like asking how a car works and some one says you turn the ignition and go. True, but hardly the whole story, and when a car needs maintenance, it requires more than that.

I think we are not as far away in what we are saying. I say that to define something means to give authority to what something is. To define means to SET parameters as to the nature of something. Gravity was discovered. You are correct when you say it has been around for as long as we existed. We did not create it. One could say (linguistically speaking) that we gave definition to it, but we did not define what it would be. We described what it already was. That is the distinction I am trying to make.

 
 We're both using acceptable definitions of the word define now IMHO, just slightly different. Define does not simply setting parameters or "creating" in the sense of the proposing of a new idea, it can also mean simply setting or creating parameters in order to record in detail an idea or a phenomenon in a singular accepted way. That's really hard to explain without using the word "define" in the definition, so I hope it's somewhat clear.
 
 I totally agree with your distinction, though I'm not sure of the point of it.
 
 I could create and name an object, purely abstract, define it, and then hope to one day discover it, or I could take an object already that already exists and measure it and describe it in detail so as to form a definition of that object that can be used to compare it to other objects. Either way, the actual discovery is trivial, or for that matter if the object even exists, it's how it's defined, and the basis for the definition that would seem to me to be important. 
 
 Anyhoo, I'm starting to confuse myself.
 
 Was gravity truly discovered? By whom? When? 
 
 When birds or monkeys drop nuts to crack them, did they just discover gravity? 
 
 Or is it simply a force we've always been aware of, like most of the laws of physics, but just simply didn't define? 
 
 Detailed scientific studies that were conducted and led to our current understanding of gravity no doubt involved some "discovery", but did that work really uncover or create anything that wasn't right in front of us for eons but simply hadn't been recorded or "defined". To be honest, I can see both sides of the coin. I think it perhaps boils down to how one defines the word discovery.
 
 IMHO, you can't discover things that are constants, like the laws of physics, you define them according to a basic understanding.
 
 You "discover" a diamond mine or a burial site.
 
 That could very well be my own bias toward the word and not reality, if so, I can accept that.

 A great analogy IMHO.

 The problem with refining this is the issue of density. If we include all the mass in a merely small space and then exploding then what we wind up with is a naked singularity (black hole or the likes). The energy measured at the big bang is acheivable only at infinite density (volume=zero).
 
 The logic behind why it had to come from somewhere is that the scientific evidence said it did not exist at some point and then it was. The question scientists ask is what was before that? It is not strictly a christian question (although christians will say they know the answer). It is part of the reason that scientists have not been able to find a grand unifying theory. One theory that ties all of the scientific disciplines together. 
 
 Even astrophysicists would not say that the universe always was. They want to know what was before. I was an astropysics major for two years in college. Switched majors when we started doing vector analysis with 6 by 6 matrices. (more math than almost any human could bear). The questions we discussed were these very items.

 The running out of gas part is the important part here. The law of entropy states that energy is running out in the universe. It is also measurable. We have measurements from long ago (big bang time) and can project the future based on the mathematical relations. There is no evidence to indicate that the energy in the universe is increasing. In fact, entropy says it MUST decrease, especially if we consider the universe a closed system. There is no evidence to suggest that we are being recharged from outside source.
